title: Add 1 Refund Credit Each Year
body:
I've heard the idea of making them reset each year, but Riot won't go for that. If such a thing were to be implemented, profits would likely go down. If we were patient, we could recycle the RP for newer and preferred products. However, I think if you have under three refund tokens left, each year you should receive one, three being the max. I for one have always hated the idea of having three acquirable points for one life time. 

P.S - I've looked at the opposition towards my fabulous idea, and I understand their point. People should be more careful about what they buy, and if you make a mistake, 3 strikes is about all you should get. I myself do a fair amount of research before purchasing something, but I still stand where I stand. 1 refund credit per year isn't asking for much, we can't abuse it, and nothing should be forever. 

Update 2-15: My post isn't getting anymore love, can all vote more yes's? :-)

I really like this idea, considering I used mine within a month not knowing I would not be receiving more ever again.  I have been a member of Leagues for under a year now and have made mistakes when buying skins (because I didn't even think to look them up) and champions that were too hard.  Then I found the magical refund button and was able to give back the champs I couldn't play and skins that I did not have a liking for.  Little did I know those were my only ones.

In short:
There should be a notification/alert telling people "Hey! These are all you get!"  I ,and other newer members, would have loved to have known that :c

The reason this needs to be implemented is because Riot is constantly making new skins for champions we already have skins for. This means You have to choose to either **A**) just stick with your old skin even though the new one is 10 times better or **B**) Get the new skin, but now the old one is completely useless and basically almost a waste of RP.

Examples:

* I have Muse Sona and Arcade Sona and for some reason Riot is taking it upon themselves to make a *legendary* Sona skin...
* I have Deep Sea (or whatever it's called) Thresh and now they come out with Bloodmoon
* I have both Justicar and Atlantean Syndra because the Atlantean one is so beautiful it's hard not to get it

Obviously this is not Riot's fault. They don't force you to buy anything. But I do think it would be incredibly notable and grand of Riot to give us **at least** one refund per year, simply for the purposes of cleaning out old skins. Since it's over years, that means you're rewarding **loyal** players who have purchased skins (or champs) in the past. AKA you're giving back to the loyal players that made you filthy rich. I don't see any negatives in that, or why anyone would be against that.
I mean of course this is a great thing.... But i don't think Riot will approve this....

Well there are also things like reworks and riot really should have a way to view the in game model of skins (since some aren't that close to their splash art)

There are many resources available for others to see how skins look in game.

1) google
2) youtube
3) other players using particular skin
4) changing default model, skin in game (most people use customs but if you REALLY must see it then do this...)

I do believe riot should make it clear how it looks and you're right most splash art is misleading (especially when it comes to trundle's skins). We live in a time where everything is readily available by the click of a button. I also get your point that visual upgrades may change how somebody views their previously bought skin. (although in most cases the texture, model, animations, and particle upgrades look 1,000 times better than the older designs.) Unless of course you preferred your pizza feet and low quality skins. That would be the only argument I could ever concede to for the sake of refunds.

I've seen champions with play styles that I thought I would enjoy but having played the champion brought on a different mindset than my perceived experience.  I'm sometimes good at ADCs, I can't play immobile carries for shiet, I'm great at tanks but find the play styles of them boring, I also excel at supporting but hate playing the role, and to top things off I can't jungle for the life of Jesus.

Why are my words relevant, well... I bought Syndra enjoyed her for a while but could never grasp what made her tick, and thus my play is ineffective, purchased Yasuo realized my mechanical skill on spamy champions is god awful, that and if my team is expecting me to carry that's pressure and with pressure I play worse as a player.

When playing a tank top or a support, the only pressure I hold is the need to get my carries ahead and that alone allows me to excel at those roles, but I of course didn't realize this upon the acquisition of Syndra and Yasuo.  Playing league allows for better insight into what the right purchases for you as a player are.  Refunds are great because they allow a player to more quickly find the role and champion they may excel at.  I primarily use IP, as do most people that appreciate refunds.

And after typing this up and reflecting on the fact that I was thinking about purchasing Jinx.  I think I'm gonna go hurt myself for my idiocy.

I personally don't like the thought of making Riot lose millions of dollars a year, even if it is due to refunds. 

I've been playing since S1 and spend a lot of money on this game, and haven't even used a single refund. It's just a matter of being careful with your money, seeing previews of the skin on youtube to get a feel for its look, and not buying a skin just for the hype around the skin (like a lot of people did with PFE). 

I think them limiting your refunds not only makes Riot more profitable, but also helps teach the gamers who are playing the game a bit of restraint, which is important in the real world. Impulse buying is never a good idea.
Even the real world is not restricted to 3 strikes and you are out.

Whether or not the world provides three strikes, or infinite strikes, is irrelevant to whether more than three strikes is really necessary for this game, or whether it's a smart business decision on Riot's part to refund millions of dollars a year (considering micro transactions and impulse buying are a key source of revenue for them).
